Fig. 1 Catalytic performance of POM over Ni/TiO2 catalyst. a) the conversion of CH4 and the selectivity of CO and H2 at 300-750°C; b) the conversion of CH4 and the selectivity of CO and H2 at 750°C hold on; c) local enlargement of b); d) the selectivity of CO2 and CO at 750°C hold on. The pictures of the Ni/TiO2 catalyst captured in the catalytic process. e) Ni/TiO2-F; f) Ni/TiO2-R; g) Ni/TiO2-A; h) Ni/TiO2-D. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Raman spectrum of the Ni/TiO2 catalysts in the catalytic process. Fig 2 Fig. 3 TG-DSC curves of the Ni/TiO2 catalysts in the flow of air. Fig 3 Fig. 4 TEM images and mapping of the Ni/TiO2 catalyst. a) and c-g) for Ni/TiO2-A; b) and h-l) for Ni/TiO2-D. Fig 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of the Ni/TiO2 catalyst. The rutile TiO2 (black), the Ni/TiO2-F (red), the Ni/TiO2-R (orange), the Ni/TiO2-A (blue), and the Ni/TiO2-D (purple). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Characterizations for the Ni/TiO2 and pure TiO2 catalysts. a) DRIFTS-CO; b) Temperature programmed reductions. The signal intensity of Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D in (a) are amplified by twenty times to facilitate comparison with the samples. Fig 6 Fig. 7 XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 on the Ni/TiO2 catalysts. a) Ni/TiO2-F; b) Ni/TiO2-R; c) Ni/TiO2-A; d) Ni/TiO2-D. Fig 7 Fig. 8 UV-Vis diffuse reflection spectrums of the Ni/TiO2-F (red trace), the Ni/TiO2-R (orange trace), the Ni/TiO2-A (blue trace), and the Ni/TiO2-D (purple trace). Fig 8 Fig. 9 CH4-TPSR test of the a) Ni/TiO2-A and b) Ni/TiO2-D catalyst with mass spectrometry. Fig 9 Fig. 10 The model of Ni/TiO2 catalyst on POM. The restructuring of a catalyst under working conditions has been recognized as a critical factor that can significantly impact their performance in recent years. In this study, we investigate the behavior of a highly dispersed Ni supported on TiO2 (P25) catalyst during the partial oxidation of methane (POM) to produce syngas. Our results reveal a distinct oscillation phenomenon in the catalyst's performance over time. The simultaneous oscillations of rapid deactivation and activation are observed, while the catalyst remains active for continuous POM reaction. Comprehensive characterizations suggest that this deactivation is not caused by traditional deactivation mechanisms with coke formation or Ni sintering. The formation of inactive NiTiO3 results in catalyst deactivation, which is formed between Ni and TiO2 support in the reductive atmosphere of POM products under high temperature due to strong metal-support interaction (SMSI). The simultaneous presence of oxidative and reductive atmospheres of the reactants and products in the POM reaction leads to the generation or demise of NiTiO3. The dynamic change of the Ni active sites during the in-situ reaction leads to the oscillation of the catalytic activity. This study sheds new light on the importance of SMSI in understanding the behavior of catalysts under working conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Partial oxidation of methane Strong metal-support interaction Syngas TiO2 Nickel Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Partial oxidation of methane (POM) is a process used to convert methane to syngas [1,2]. The main reaction (1) and possible side reactions (2-11) during the POM reaction are summarized in Scheme 1 . The POM process is complicated owing to the existence of numerous reaction routes. Besides the main reaction to produce syngas CO and H2 (1), the side reactions of deep catalytic oxidative products of CO2 and H2O (2-4, 7-9), reforming reaction (5-6), as well as coke deposition (9-11) are also existed. The content of O2 has a great influence on the selection of reactions. The POM catalysts mainly include the Ni-based catalysts [4,5] and noble metal-based catalysts [6–12]. However, due to the cost and availability of noble metals, extensive research interests have been conducted on Ni-based catalysts correspondingly [13,14]. So far, the main challenge of Ni-based catalysts is the catalyst deactivation under harsh reaction conditions such as high temperature, the existence of both oxidative and reductive atmosphere [15–18]. Numerous studies have revealed that the deactivation is mainly caused by deposition of carbon on the catalyst surface, especially in high-temperature reactions [19–22]. Meanwhile, Ni particles sintering, and consequently loss of surface area as well as structural changes of the mixed oxide phase are also identified as deactivation mechanisms [23–29]. To overcome this challenge, researchers have investigated various approaches, including introducing promoters [30], regulating the alloy composition [31], and constructing the nanostructure of the catalyst [32]. Unfortunately, the problem of nickel catalyst deactivation in POM has not yet been completely resolved [33,34]. Recently, numerous oxides such as Al2O3, MgO, SiO2, CaO, Y2O3, La2O3, CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2 and Ta2O5 have been widely investigated as the supports for the developing of POM catalysts [13,25,28,35,36]. Among those supports, TiO2 has been shown to an excellent support to activate methane to syngas as a reducible metal oxide [7,9,37,38]. Notably, strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) was first reported on TiO2 based catalyst [39,40]. It was found that TiO2 could generate SMSI phenomenon with the supported metal under high temperature and reductive atmosphere. SMSI could modify the catalytic activity of supported metal catalyst by changing the surface structure or electron state of catalysts [41,42]. Considering that the catalyst may undergoes restructuring under reactive environment, the SMSI is a critical factor that could significantly impact the catalytic performance [43]. Nevertheless, the atmosphere in the POM reaction is complex since the reactants are oxidative atmosphere, whereas the products are reductive [44]. The correlation between the unique atmospheres on the SMSI and consequent POM performance has not been fully explored. Therefore, it is crucial to investigate the POM reaction process under the influence of SMSI. In our previous work [44], we discovered that a Ir/TiO2 catalyst exhibited an unusual activity switching phenomenon during the POM reaction, which was caused by the shift from an oxidative atmosphere to a reductive atmosphere during the reaction, exposing the catalytic active sites gradually. Furthermore, SMSI resulted in the modification of the active site, presenting an initial induction period of catalytic activity [44]. In this study, we investigated the behavior of the 1 wt% Ni/TiO2 catalyst during the POM reaction. An unexpected oscillation phenomenon in the catalyst stability study was observed, which could be easily ignored in the catalyst with high metal loading or high mass feeding of the catalyst by providing more active sites. The catalyst was deactivated rapidly, however, then re-activated simultaneously on the time of stream. This oscillation between deactivation and recover was observed for multiple times on the time of stream. It is hypothesized that the oscillation in activity is attributed to the catalyst structure change in reactive atmosphere from an oxidative to a reductive atmosphere during the reaction process. To examine the hypothesis, the catalyst was captured at various status including fresh (F), reduced (R), activated (A) and deactivated (D) for further investigation. The chemical state of Ni in the catalyst was investigated by Raman spectrum, thermal gravity-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC), Transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), diffusive reflectance infrared Fourier transformed spectrum of adsorbed CO (DRIFTS-CO), X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) and diffusive reflectance UV visible spectrum (DR UV-Vis). The deactivation behavior of the catalyst is found to be correlated to the formation of NiTiO3 species during the POM reaction process. The dynamic change of the Ni active sites during the in-situ reaction leads to the oscillation of the catalytic activity. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals used in this experiment were analytical grade and used without further purification. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98 wt%) was ordered from Shanghai Aladdin Biochem Technology Co. LTD as metal precursor. The commercial TiO2 (P25, 99.5 wt%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. LTD as the support. Other chemicals were used as received. All gases were purchased from Linde Industrial Gases with purity higher than 99.99%. Ni/TiO2 catalyst was synthesized with a modified deposition-precipitation (DP) method [45]. In a typical preparation, 1.0 g TiO2 was mixed with 150 mL deionized water through a vigorous stirring to form a white suspension. 20 mL Ni(NO3)2·6H2O aqueous solution (contain 50.6 mg Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) was added to the TiO2 suspension slowly through controlled injection with a syringe pump in a rate of 200 μL/min while the solution was vigorously stirred. The new suspension was continuously stirred for 2 h. Then, the ammonia solution was added dropwise into the suspension under vigorous stirring with the pH value of the mixture was carefully adjusted to 9.5. Then the mixture was further vigorously stirred for 5 h to obtain a complete equilibrium solution. After the DP procedure, the sample was washed with water and then centrifuged, vacuum-dried, and finally calcined at 700°C for 6 h in air with a ramping rate of 2°C/min. The catalyst was captured at various status during the reaction process including fresh (F), reduced (R), activated (A) and deactivated (D) for investigation. The activated and deactivated catalysts were collected at about 370 min and 5460 min, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization A Titan Chemi-Stem FEI Talos 200X (USA) transmission electron microscopy was used to collect the TEM images. A Smart Lab SE X-ray diffractometer (Japan) equipped with Cu Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 40 mA was used to collect the XRD patterns. The diffraction patterns are referenced to the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) database. A Thermo Scientific iCAP 7000 Series (USA) was used to investigate the element content via ICP-OES test. A Micromeritics ASAP 2020 PLUS (USA) using N2 adsorption was used for BET performed. A Thermo Scientific Raman imaging microscope DXR2xi (USA) equipped with 532 nm laser excitation was used to collect the Raman spectra. A Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 3+ (USA) was used to conduct TG-DSC data. Air was the feeding gas during the TG-DSC test with a ramping rate of 10°C/min. An Agilent Technologies Cary 7000 (USA) was used to collect UV-Vis-DR spectra. A Thermo Fisher Scientific iS50 FT-IR spectrometer (USA) equipped with an MCT detector and a Harrick Scientific Products praying mantis cell (USA) was used to collect the DRIFTS-CO spectra. 32 data scans at a resolution of 4 cm–1 were recorded for each spectrum. An in-situ pre-treatment in Ar flow at 300°C (30 min) for the sample was made before data collection. A background spectrum was taken after pre-treatment in Ar flow at room temperature. CO (5% in Ar) was introduced for 30 min then shut down, with the Ar flow kept to purge out the CO. Spectra were recorded after the CO shut down 30 min later. All spectra were subtracted by a background spectrum of the fresh surface taken in Ar flow at 25°C. Temperature programmed experiments were performed on an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA). A pre-treatment was performed in Helium at 300°C for 30 min. In a typical TPR experiment: 0.2 g catalyst (40-60 mesh) was treated by heating to 850°C in H2 (10% in Ar). In the CO pulse chemisorption analysis: 0.2 g catalyst (40-60 mesh) was flushed by pulsed CO (10% in Ar) for 20 times with the measured flow rate at 1.347 mmol/min. All the signals were recorded by a TCD detector equipped with a MS-13X column. All the ramp rates in this part were 10°C/min. The ratio of surface Ni atoms available for CO adsorption to the total number of Ni atoms, is used in this work as a measurement of Ni metal dispersion [46]. Ni metal dispersion was calculated according to the below equation. M e t a l d i s p e r s i o n ( N i ) = V c h e m * S F * M W ( Ni ) C I C P * 100 % In the typcial evaluation, the V chem = 128.39 μmol/g, is the cumulative quantity of CO molecule; SF = 1, is the Stoichiometry Factor. According to the DRIFTS-CO, CO was predominantly via a linear single point attachment on the surface of Ni/TiO2-F catalyst. Therefore, the stoichiometry factor = 1 is accordingly taken as a reasonable estimate in determining Ni dispersion; MW(Ni) = 58.71 g/mol, is the atomic mass unit of Ni. For the temperature programmed surface reaction of CH4 (CH4-TPSR): 50 mg catalyst (40-60 mesh) was pre-treated in Ar at 300°C for 1 h with a ramping rate of 10°C/min, then the reactant gas of CH4 (5% in Ar) was introduced at a flow of 1.5 mL/min with the increase of temperature from 100°C to 750°C at the same rate of 10°C/min. Throughout the process, the effluent was recorded on an online mass spectrometer at the m/z intensities of H2 (2), CO (28), CO2 (44), and CH4 (16) [47]. XPS measurements were performed in a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi (USA) equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source with a spot size of 400 μm, a passing energy of 50 eV, and a resolution of 0.1 eV. The deconvolution of the XPS spectrum was performed by the Avantage software with the Lorentzian-Gaussian value fixed at 25%. The FWHM of the Ni2+ and Ni0 peak was fixed at 1.7 and 1.5, respectively. All data were fitted using Smart mode minus the baseline. The Ti/Ni ratio was calculated by the total atomic ratio of Ti and Ni which measured by the peak area of XPS. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation A catalytic test was performed on a fix-bed quartz tube reactor (inner diameter = 6 mm), equipped with an online gas chromatograph (Shimazu GC-2014, Japan). Gaseous products were analyzed online by a HP-AL/S column and a MS-13X column which connects with an FID detector and a TCD detector, respectively. A K-type thermocouple coated was used to monitor the temperature during the reaction. 50 mg catalyst (40-60 mesh) was mixed with 300 mg quartz sand (40-60 mesh). The quartz sand was washed by aqua regia and dried before using. The catalyst was in-situ pre-treated in H2 (5% in Ar, 40 mL/min) at 700°C for 2 h. Then the temperature was cooled down to 300°C with changing the gas to the reactant gases. The reactant gases were at a total flow rate of 45 mL/min, including CH4 (5% in Ar) and O2 (5% in Ar), where concentration were 3.2 and 1.6%, respectively. The reactions were carried out with 5.4 L gcat −1 h−1. Activities were measured from 300 to 750°C only when the concentration and selectivity were stable. Conversion and selectivity were calculated according to the below equations. C o n v e r s i o n ( C H 4 ) = [ C H 4 ] 0 − [ C H 4 ] T [ C H 4 ] 0 * 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y ( H 2 ) = 1 2 * [ H 2 ] [ C H 4 ] 0 − [ C H 4 ] T * 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y ( C O ) = [ C O ] [ C H 4 ] 0 − [ C H 4 ] T * 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y ( C O 2 ) = [ C O 2 ] [ C H 4 ] 0 − [ C H 4 ] T * 100 % Whereas [CH4]0 is the inlet CH4 concentration, and [CH4]T is the outlet CH4 concentration at temperature T. [H2], [CO], and [CO2] stand for H2, CO, and CO2 concentration in the outlet of the reactor at the desired temperature, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of Ni/TiO2 catalyst in POM As prepared, the authentic Ni content in the Ni/TiO2 catalyst was confirmed to be 0.91 wt% by ICP-OES, which is close to the nominal 1.0 wt%. The physicochemical properties of pure TiO2 support and Ni/TiO2 catalyst are summarized in Table S1. The dispersion of Ni in the catalyst was measured as 82.8% by chemisorption analysis of pulsed CO. The catalytic performance of Ni/TiO2 catalyst was studied for POM reaction (Fig. 1 ). First of all, the experiment with primitive TiO2 support was examined (Fig. S1), indicating no POM activity over TiO2 support. Secondly, according to the catalytic performance of Ni/TiO2 catalyst in Fig. 1a, the conversion of CH4 is as low as 14.6% with minimum syngas (CO and H2) production at the temperature below 700°C. However, when the reaction temperature was increased to 750°C, the conversion of CH4 increased rapidly from 14.6 to 89.8%. The selectivity to CO and H2 also increased to 95.8 and 77.1 %, respectively. Thus, the Ni/TiO2 catalyst is active for POM when the temperature is higher than 750°C. The stability of the catalyst at 750°C is shown in Fig. 1b–d. The conversion of CH4 and the selectivity toward H2, CO, and CO2 are demonstrated. On the time of stream, the conversion of CH4 decreases occasionally, and the selectivity to CO and H2 decreases following the same trend with the conversion of CH4 (Fig. 1b), with the increasing of the selectivity of CO2 (Fig. 1d). The local enlargement of Fig. 1b is shown in Fig. 1c. When the catalytic activity decreases to a certain extent (for example, at about 1711 min in Fig. 1c), the conversion of CH4 and the selectivity of H2 and CO recovers rapidly, while the selectivity of CO2 decreases rapidly. Then, with the further incremental reaction time, the catalytic activity deactivates and recovers for multiple times. The catalytic activity data showes an oscillating trend. In the test time range of about 5500 min, the fluctuation range of CH4 conversion is about 9.3–89.8%. The selectivity of the H2, CO and CO2 are 0.8–89.5, 16.2–94.2 and 2.0-57.5%, respectively. The fluctuation range is too large to be ignored. Therefore, an oscillation phenomenon of the POM activity is observed. As a control experiment, we increased the catalyst weight to 500 mg on POM reaction test under the same test conditions (Fig. S2a). The control experiment result shows that the catalyst has good stability. Within about 1500 min the CH4 conversion reaches 99.1%, H2 and CO selectivity are 82.8 and 96.7%, respectively. After 1500 min, the catalytic activity began to decrease slightly. And after 2500 min, the CH4 conversion decreases to 89.2%, while the selectivity of H2 and CO are 80.3% and 88.6%, respectively. In other words, high mass feeding results in the disappearance of oscillation phenomenon because excess active sites are provided, therefore this phenomenon is covered during the studies. Dissanayake et al. [48] used a low mass feeding (50 mg) of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst on POM reaction, and found that the catalyst bed stratified, while the active sites of Ni species had three states: Ni0, NiO and NiAl2O4. Therefore, low mass feeding may be more conducive to explore the change of catalytic active sites. In addition, the stability study of the 8 wt% Ni/TiO2 catalyst at 750°C on POM reaction was also recorded (Fig. S2b), which shows no oscillation phenomenon during about 1800 min on stream. The CH4 conversion reaches 94.3%, H2 and CO selectivity are 91.4% and 99.3%, respectively. The oscillation phenomenon is also to be covered in the catalyst with high loading which can provides excess active sites. Therefore, low mass feeding and low metal loading may be more conducive to explore the change of catalytic active sites. The control experiments eliminate the possible fluctuations of temperatures or hot-spot in the catalyst bed. Via comparing with the results of experimental group (Fig. 1b) and control group (Fig. S2a), it is confirmed that: (1) the fluctuations of POM performance are not caused by the reactor's own factors; (2) the deactivation mechanism of those two groups may be different. The activity of the experimental group can be restored by oscillation, while the activity of most of other experiments cannot be restored. Generally, it is generally believed that carbon deposition and Ni sintering are two main deactivation mechanisms over POM reaction according to mostly literature report. In order to study the deactivation mechanism of this special phenomenon in the experimental group, four different catalysts during the experiment were collected for a series of characterization studies: (1) The fresh Ni/TiO2 before catalysis (Ni/TiO2-F); 2) The Ni/TiO2 after reduction by H2 at 700°C for 1 h (Ni/TiO2-R); 3) The Ni/TiO2 after catalysis with active sites (Ni/TiO2-A); 4) The Ni/TiO2 after catalysis with deactivated sites (Ni/TiO2-D). Correspondingly, The Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D during the reaction were circled in Fig. 1c. Moreover, the catalyst after the experimental reaction in the control group which used 500 mg Ni/TiO2 catalyst for POM reaction (Ni/TiO2-C) was also collected. 3.2 Reveal the change on the active sites for POM The catalyst at various states (F, R, A and D) show distinct color, as shown in Fig. 1e-h. The Ni/TiO2-F and Ni/TiO2-D exhibit the same color of light yellow and are nonmagnetic. As the contrast, the Ni/TiO2-R is dark grey while Ni/TiO2-A is light grey. Both Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-A are magnetic, indicating that Ni metal exists on the surface of the catalyst. The picture of Ni/TiO2-C is also added in the Fig. S3, which is light grey and magnetic resembling to the Ni/TiO2-A. Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D are in different colors, although both of them are spent catalysts over POM reaction. Correspondingly, a series of characterizations were adopted to investigate the surface structures of catalysts. Firstly, Raman spectrum was performed on the collected catalysts. The full range of Raman spectrum is shown in Fig. S4a. Compared with the pure TiO2, the signals are significantly enhanced after loading Ni species. Fig. S4b shows the zoom-in of Raman spectrum at 50–850 cm−1. The signal value of pure TiO2 is amplified by ten times to facilitate comparison with the samples. All peaks in the figure could be attributed to anatase (A) phase and rutile (R) phase of TiO2 (Fig. S4b) [49]. No NiO peak is found at about 490 cm−1 [50], which could be due to the low Ni loading or high dispersion of Ni. The zoom-in of Raman spectrum at 1300–1700 cm−1 is shown in Fig. 2 . The catalysts all display no peaks around 1350 and 1590 cm − 1 in Raman spectra, which are assigned to D-band and G-band of carbon materials, respectively [51], indicating that there is no carbon deposition in the catalyst before and after the reaction. The Raman spectrum of the Ni/TiO2-C is also added in the Fig. S5. Similarly, no obvious peaks are found at 1350 and 1590 cm − 1 in Ni/TiO2-C catalyst, indicating that there is no carbon deposition on the surface. Combined with the catalytic performance of the control experiment in Figs. 1b and S2, the catalytic activity decreases with oscillation phenomenon in experimental group and decreases slightly with the further incremental reaction time in control group. Although the deactivation phenomenon in experimental group and control group is different, carbon deposition is not the deactivation mechanism in both two groups. The TG-DSC results are shown in Fig. 3 . The Ni/TiO2-F catalyst shows the total mass loss about 1.5% from room temperature, which could be ascribed to the elimination of the surface hydroxyl group, hydrated water molecules or other chemicals [52]. A subtle mass loss about 0.1% are found at 200–400°C in the Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts, corresponding to the combustion of active carbon that was considered as non-threatening species for the catalytic activity [53]. In addition, no peak of the graphite coke that could lead to catalyst deactivation is found above 500°C on all the prepared catalysts. The DSC results show the rate of temperature change during the test. Above 400°C, more NiTiO3 species are generated in Ni/TiO2-A catalyst due to the calcination of high temperature in the air, leading to the increase of total mass and the exothermicity [54]. The TG-DSC results further confirm that carbon deposition during the POM reaction is negligible and the carbon deposition is not the deactivation mechanism for Ni/TiO2-D. The TEM images of Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D are shown in Fig. 4 . The lattice fringe of TiO2 support is found at 0.32 nm, which is assigned to the (110) plane of rutile TiO2. The lattice fringe of Ni (111) is found at 0.20 nm, indicating that Ni metal exists on the surface of Ni/TiO2-A, which is the active center of POM reaction [55]. Compared with the highly dispersion of O and Ti elements, the Ni elements on the surface of Ni/TiO2-A (Fig. 4c–g) are partially aggregated. Surprisingly, the Ni element in Ni/TiO2-D (Fig. 4h–l) is better dispersed than Ni/TiO2-A. Therefore, it could be concluded that the sintering of Ni on the surface is not the reason for the deactivation on Ni/TiO2-D. Moreover, the lattice fringes of TiO2 support are found at 0.16 and 0.20 nm, which are assigned to the (220) and (210) plane of rutile TiO2 (Fig. 4b). We do not find any lattice fringe of metallic Ni on the Ni/TiO2-D surface, while the lattice fringe of NiTiO3 at 0.23 nm (113) is observed, suggesting the Ni active sites change to NiTiO3 species to deactivate the Ni/TiO2-D catalyst. To further confirm the cause of catalyst deactivation over Ni/TiO2-D catalyst, the XRD patterns of the Ni/TiO2 catalysts were approached, as shown in Fig. 5 . The diffraction patterns of the Ni/TiO2-F and Ni/TiO2-R exhibit the P25 TiO2 patterns corresponding to the powder diffraction files (PDF) JCPDS-21-1276 (rutile) and JCPDS-21-1272 (anatase). After catalysis the diffraction patterns exhibit the rutile TiO2 patterns merely (Fig. S6). Moreover, it is noted that some peaks are observed including NiTiO3 (33.2o, JCPDS-33-0960, Fig. 5a), NiO (37.3o, JCPDS-47-1049, Fig. 5b), and Ni metal (44.6o, JCPDS-65-0380, Fig. 5c) [14]. Thus, the XRD data shows that Ni/TiO2-A contained NiTiO3 and NiO phase, while no peak of Ni metal species is found. Ni cations in NiO or NiTiO3 is not active for POM compared with metallic Ni [35,55–57]. In terms of the Ni/TiO2-R after pre-treatment by H2, NiTiO3 was reduced to Ni metal, but the peak of NiO still existed. After catalytic reaction, the Ni/TiO2-A maintained a weak peak of Ni metal. The peaks of the NiO and anatase TiO2 disappeared due to the reductive product atmosphere at high temperature to cause the phase change. The Ni peaks disappeared and the NiTiO3 peaks appeared in the Ni/TiO2-D. This observation is consistent with the TEM results. Compared with Ni/TiO2-F catalyst, the peak of NiTiO3 in the Ni/TiO2-D catalyst is blue shifted by 0.1 degree. According to the Bragg equation, the XRD data convert the signal related to the value of interplanar distance (d) into a one-dimensional signal relationship related to the angle of incidence (θ). As a result, the interplanar distance becomes larger, and the Angle of incidence θ becomes smaller. The doping of Ti atom into NiO lattice results in lattice deformation and larger interplanar distance. More NiTiO3 species was produced in the Ni/TiO2-D catalyst. The XRD patterns of the Ni/TiO2-C is also characterized in Figs. S7 and S6. No peak of NiTiO3 or NiO species is found, while Ni metal peak is found in 44.6o. The Ni/TiO2-C is similar to the Ni/TiO2-A. Hence, it is proposed that the Ni/TiO2-C/A and the Ni/TiO2-D have different Ni species in the surface of the catalyst. The Ni/TiO2-C and Ni/TiO2-A still show POM catalytic activity because of the existence of exposed metallic Ni active sites, while the deactivation of Ni/TiO2-D is due to the disappearance of Ni metal species. To unveil the electronic state of Ni in the catalyst, DRIFTS-CO of the Ni/TiO2 catalysts and pure TiO2 are shown in Fig. 6 a. The signal value of Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D are amplified by twenty times to facilitate comparison with the samples. No obvious peak is observed over pure TiO2, demonstrating that the signals on the Ni/TiO2 catalysts are related to the Ni sites. Only one significant peak is found on the Ni/TiO2-F catalyst at 2038 cm−1 in the range of 1800–2200 cm−1, which is attributed to the linear bonded of CO on the Ni site [58,59]. No bridge bonded peak is found at 1800–2000 cm−1, indicating that the Ni specis on the Ni/TiO2-F catalyst are highly dispersed. Two peaks are found on both the Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-A catalysts at 2038 and 1926 cm−1, which are attributed to the linear and bridge bonded of CO on the Ni sites [58,59], respectively, indicating that the Ni elements on the surface of Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-A are partially aggregated. This observation is consistent with the TEM results. No obvious peak is observed over Ni/TiO2-D catalyst. Combined with XRD results, we believe that DRIFTS-CO peaks are related to the NiO and Ni metal, rather than the NiTiO3. The Ni/TiO2-F catalyst showed a CO adsorption peak due to the presence of NiO. No CO adsorption peak was observed on the Ni/TiO2-D catalyst due to the active sites completely changed to NiTiO3. The TPR data are shown in Fig. 6b. The TiO2 support shows no obvious peak, while the Ni/TiO2-F contains two peaks at 396°C and 588°C, corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO and NiTiO3 species, respectively [14,37]. The TPR results for the Ni/TiO2-F catalyst are consistent with the XRD results. The pre-treatment temperature on 700°C can completely reduce the NiO and NiTiO3 in the Ni/TiO2-F. Therefore, the NiO species observed over Ni/TiO2-R from the XRD data in Fig. 5b should be caused by the exposure of catalyst in the air, indicating that the reduced Ni metal active site is easily to be oxidized. This is also consistent with the POM catalytic results in Fig. 1a, demonstrating that the reduced catalyst Ni/TiO2-R is very susceptible to the oxidative environmental atmosphere, resulting in the passivation of the Ni metal active site on the surface of the catalyst and then the deactivation of the catalyst at low temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of the Ni/TiO2 before and after catalysis processes are performed to identify the differences about the chemical valence of Ni. The deconvolution of the XPS spectrum is performed with reference of C 1s to at 284.8 eV in Fig. S8a. As shown in Fig. 7 , the strong peak centered at ∼855.5 eV is assigned to the Ni 2p3/2 peak of Ni2+ species, along with a satellite peak at ∼861.3 eV above the Ni2+ species [60]. Fig. 7b and 7c show that the small peaks at binding energies of ∼853.3 eV are observed in the Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-A, which corresponds well to the Ni 2p3/2 peak of metallic Ni0, along with a satellite at ∼857.1 eV above the metallic Ni0 species [37,61]. The XPS data indicated that only Ni2+ species exists in the Ni/TiO2-F catalyst before the reaction, but part of Ni2+ species are reduced to metallic Ni0 species after reduction. After the reaction, the Ni/TiO2-A retains the active metallic Ni0 site. Due to the exposure in the air, the Ni/TiO2-D only has Ni2+species. The more XPS signals of Ti and O are added in the Fig. S8b and S8c. Due to the low Ni loading, O and Ti signals are similar. The quantitative analysis result of the XPS spectra for the Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts are shown in Table 1 . The Ti/Ni atomic ratio in Ni/TiO2-A catalyst is 9.8%, and is increased to 11.8% in Ni/TiO2-D catalyst, indicating that the ratio of Ti atoms on the surface of catalyst after deactivation is more than that of Ni/TiO2-A. All the Ti atoms in the catalysts are provided by the TiO2 support. It is proved that the transition from Ni/TiO2-A to Ni/TiO2-D is accompanied by the migration of Ti atoms from the support to the surface of catalyst. Combined with the catalytic activity, the catalyst changed between Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D during the reaction process for multiple times on the time of stream, indicating that the SMSI induced by the reaction atmosphere changed. The Ti atoms migrated and disappeared repeatedly, made the active sites changed between Ni and NiTiO3 repeatedly, resulting in the oscillation phenomenon between deactivation and recover in the catalyst's performance over time. UV-Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) was performed to study the optical absorption characteristics of the samples. As shown in Figs. 8 and S9, all catalysts show intense absorption below 400 nm due to the intrinsic band gap of the TiO2 support by electron transition from the valence to the conduction band [62]. The peaks above 400 nm are assigned to Ni2+→Ti4+ metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) [63]. The Ni/TiO2-F and Ni/TiO2-D samples show minor peaks at 450, 510, and 743 nm, which are attributed to the NiTiO3 phase [5,64,65]. The spectra at 450 and 510 nm are due to the splitting of the crystal field of the d-d transition of Ni2+ [64]. The spectra at 743 nm is indicated by its yellow color [65]. UV-Vis DRS results showed that Ni species in Ni/TiO2-F and Ni/TiO2-D are NiTiO3, while the Ni metal species mainly exists in Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-R catalysts. The CH4-TPSR test for the Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts as shown in Fig. 9 . CH4 was introduce to the surface of the catalyst during the test. No external O2 was used. Therefore, the O involved in the CH4-TPSR was provided by the catalyst itself for the CH4-TPSR test in the form of stoichiometric lattice oxygen from the TiO2 support. [47] A small amount of O species exists on the surface of Ni/TiO2-A catalysts due to exposure in the air. As shown in Fig. 9a, CH4 has a weak peak for consumption at about 180°C in the Ni/TiO2-A catalyst. The POM reaction proceeds with the introduced CH4 flow and the O species on the surface of catalyst at the Ni0 active site, producing CO and H2. A wide peak of CO is observed. No remaining H2 is detected, because a part of the H2 is used to reduce the oxygen on the surface of the catalyst and other part of the H2 is used to reduce the TiO2 support. With the increase of temperature, a small amount of CO2 products gradually increased, which proved the existence of the side reaction of complete oxidation of methane. Significant peaks of CO2, CO, and H2 are observed when the temperature is risen to about 500°C. It is worth noting that the CO and H2 signals increase gradually with the increasing temperature, showing significantly different growth rates in the range of 470–510°C and 510–750°C, indicating that the products CO and H2 are mainly due to the contribution of the two reactions. Combined with the catalytic performance, we believe that both Ni0 and NiTiO3 active sites could be existed above 500°C, and the POM reaction and other side reactions occur simultaneously, leading to the superposition of CO and H2 signals. The reduction of the support provides more oxygen to the reactions, leading to the slow occurrence of the main reaction and the side reactions. As shown in Fig. 9b, unlike the Ni/TiO2-A catalyst, POM reaction did not occur on the Ni/TiO2-D catalyst at low temperature due to the absence of Ni0 active site. A very small amount of peak for CO2 is detected gradually with the increased temperature above 300°C, which also proved that the side reaction of complete oxidation of methane occurred on the catalyst surface. As there is more O species on the surface of Ni/TiO2-D catalyst than Ni/TiO2-A catalyst, and the oxidation reaction is faster. A significant decrease in CH4 is detected at about 570°C, while sharp peaks of CO2, CO, and H2 are observed. The maximum of CO2 signal is found at 573°C. At the same time, the highest signal values of CO and H2 are detected at about 576°C. It is believed that the main reaction and side reactions occurred at the same time, leading to the generation of a large amount of CO and H2. Part of the generated H2 is rapidly used to reduce the NiTiO3 active sites, and the active sites gradually change from NiTiO3 to Ni0. The contribution of side reactions is reduced, and the signal values of CO and H2 decreases correspondingly. The results of TPSR showed that the Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts contain different active sites and showed different catalytic activities under the feeding of only CH4 flow. The SMSI effect induced by reaction atmosphere changed the active site of catalyst. This is the fundamental cause of the oscillation of catalytic activity. The results of surface reaction are consistent with those of catalytic performance test. Combined with above XRD, XPS, UV-Vis DRS, TPRS, and catalytic performance results, Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-A showed high POM catalytic activity due to the presence of metallic Ni0 active site, while the Ni/TiO2-F and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts only contain Ni2+ species without POM activity. The catalytic performance of Ni/TiO2 catalyst is discussed as shown in Fig. 10 . First of all, the characterization results show that when the prepared catalyst (Ni/TiO2-F) is calcined in the air by muffle furnace, SMSI occurs between TiO2 and Ni to generate NiTiO3 species [64]. Through the high temperature reduction (Ni/TiO2-R), the NiTiO3 obtained by air calcination could be reduced to Ni metal and rutile TiO2. Then, at the initial stage of the process, low catalytic performance is observed in POM reaction. The low activity at lower temperature is attributed to the oxidative reactive atmosphere (CH4+O2), which could passivate the metal active site, and further result in minor activity of methane activation at low temperature [44]. However, the produced H2 can reduce the passivated Ni sites to metallic Ni0 species. With the further increasing of the reaction temperature, the Ni species are fully reduced to metallic Ni0 state (Ni/TiO2-A), which is active for POM reaction [44]. Nevertheless, in the process of POM reaction, the reductive product H2 and the high temperature of 750°C will further cause SMSI between the TiO2 on rutile phase and the Ni species to generate NiTiO3. Recently, Monal et al. [66] also used scanning transmission electron microscopy and infrared spectroscopy to demonstrate that high-temperature reduction would lead to the reduction of the support in the Ni/TiO2 catalyst, resulting in only part of the Ni re-exposed to the surface in the carbon dioxide hydrogenation reaction. In this work, the metallic Ni0 active sites decreased gradually, while the NiTiO3 species increased, leading to a decreased catalytic activity. When the H2 is decreased to a certain level, the O2 in the environment will not be enough to be completely consumed by CH4. In the similar manner, Frey et al. [41] through the in-situ TEM intuitively found that under H2 atmosphere, the TiO2 support migrated to the Pt particles surface due to the SMSI; under H2+O2 atmosphere, the migrated TiO2 on the Pt particles surface disappeared. Therefore, in this work we propose that, when H2 is decreased to a certain extent, the H2+O2 environment will make NiTiO3 species turn into Ni and rutile TiO2 again. The metallic Ni0 active sites were exposed on the surface of the catalyst again, and the catalytic activity was rapidly restored. The classical SMSI in the reduction environment at high temperature effect on the TiO2 reduced and migrated to the surface of metal Ni and formed the NiTiO3. The decrease of active site Ni0 led to the decrease of the CH4 conversion. The H2+O2 environmental atmosphere at high temperature weakened the classical SMSI. The disappearance of NiTiO3 exposed the metal Ni0 sites, leading to the recovery of the CH4 conversion. The generation and weakened of SMSI effect need to be induced by different environmental conditions. The different reaction rates led to the slow decline and rapid recovery of CH4 conversion. With the increase of reductive products, SMSI will occur again in Ni and TiO2. Therefore, the catalytic activity showed the oscillation by the change of environmental atmosphere. Increasing the amount of catalyst can avoid the oscillation of catalyst deactivation (Fig. S2), because the excess active sites can reduce the effect of TiO2 migrate to a small number of Ni sites. 3.3 Discussion 3.3.1 Discussion for carbon deposition on the catalysts First, the C1s peaks as show in Fig. S8a did not increase significantly from Ni/TiO2-A to Ni/TiO2-D, indicating that the content of C was stable and no significantly amount of C-C bonds were generated during the reaction. [9] Moreover, if carbon deposition was produced, the metal Ni0 active sites on the catalyst surface should be covered, which could act as the active sites to produce coke. [67,68] On the one hand, the carbon will prevent the reaction atmosphere from contacting the active sites, and resulting in a significant decrease in catalytic activity. In addition, it also will prevent the phase transition to NiTiO3. Many characterization results in this work such as XRD, UV-Vis DRS, TEM showed that NiTiO3 species were generated in Ni/TiO2-D catalyst. Therefore, it is believed that carbon deposition is negligible, and not the cause of the decrease in activity. In addition, all the catalysts display no peaks around 1350 and 1590 cm − 1 in Raman spectra (Fig. 2), which are assigned to D-band and G-band of carbon, respectively, [51] indicating that there is no carbon deposition in the catalyst before and after the reaction. Moreover, carbon deposition usually causes the catalyst to be dark black in color. However, Fig. 1f and 1g show that both Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-C catalysts are in gray, which is caused by reduced metal Ni0 (Fig. 7b and 7c), rather than carbon deposition. In conclusion, there is no carbon deposition affecting catalytic activity during the catalytic process. 3.3.2 Discussion on the surface NiTiO3 investigated by the surface sensitive characterizations Considering the catalytic reaction is a surface-sensitive chemical reaction, only the chemical species on the surface of the substance participate in the catalytic performance. Therefore, we focus on the statues of Ni species that is mainly on the surface of the catalyst. In this work, surface sensitive techniques such as XPS, DRIFTS-CO and CH4-TPSR were used to analyze the structural changes of active sites on the catalyst surface. As long as the proportion of surface NiTiO3 species overrides that of metallic Ni0, it can play a decisive role in the structure of the substance and change the catalytic activity of the catalyst. According to the DRIFTS-CO (Fig. 6a), CO was predominantly adsorbed on the surface of Ni/TiO2-F catalyst via a linear geometry due to the presence of NiO species. Obviously, linear and bridge signals were observed on both the Ni/TiO2-R and Ni/TiO2-A catalysts due to the reducing of the metal Ni0 active sites. [58,59] Moreover, no obvious peak is observed over Ni/TiO2-D catalyst because all the Ni species on the catalyst surface are converted to NiTiO3. The DRIFTS-CO results show that the proportion of NiTiO3 on the surface of Ni/TiO2-D catalyst is higher than that of Ni/TiO2-A catalyst, and the proportion of Ni0 active site is lower, so the catalytic activity is lower, which is consistent with the results of catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 7, XPS spectra also observed obvious metallic Ni0 signal of Ni/TiO2-A catalyst, while there was only Ni2+ signal in Ni/TiO2-D catalyst. The CH4-TPSR test for the Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts are shown in Fig. 9. The Ni/TiO2-A catalyst could catalyse the POM reaction stoichiometric with the introduced CH4 flow at low temperature due to the presence of the metal Ni0 active site on the surface, producing CO. However, only NiTiO3 existed on the surface of Ni/TiO2-D catalyst, consequently only a small amount of CO2 is generated by the side reaction at low temperature. The results of CH4-TPSR test show that the reactivity of Ni species on the surface of Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts are different, which leads to different catalytic properties. The surface sensitive technologies such as XPS, DRIFTS-CO and CH4-TPSR jointly explain the difference in the structure of active sites on the surface of Ni/TiO2-A and Ni/TiO2-D catalysts. The formation of NiTiO3 species leads to the difference in catalytic activity of the two catalysts. 4 Conclusions The transient structure and dynamic catalytic behavior of the Ni/TiO2 catalyst on POM reaction was investigated in this study. The stability of the catalyst during the POM reaction exhibited an unusual oscillatory between deactivation and regeneration, which was not attributed to carbon deposition or Ni sintering. Raman spectra revealed that no carbon deposition was detected on the deactivated catalyst, and the TG-DSC results further confirmed that carbon deposition during the POM reaction is negligible. TEM images showed a more dispersed Ni species without Ni sintering over the deactivated catalyst. Comprehensive studies such as XRD, TPR, XPS, TPRS, UV-Vis DRS confirmed that the formation of NiTiO3 led to the catalyst deactivation. The study revealed that the environmental atmosphere changes to H2/H2+O2 during POM reaction, leading to the appearance/disappearance of SMSI between TiO2 support and Ni. The active site changes to NiTiO3 or Ni, resulting in the oscillatory deactivation phenomenon. This work reveals the significance of SMSI in influencing the activity of high dispersion catalysts during the reaction and provides new insight into designing Ni-based catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The restructuring of a catalyst under working conditions has been recognized as a critical factor that can significantly impact their performance in recent years. In this study, we investigate the behavior of a highly dispersed Ni supported on TiO2 (P25) catalyst during the partial oxidation of methane (POM) to produce syngas. Our results reveal a distinct oscillation phenomenon in the catalyst's performance over time. The simultaneous oscillations of rapid deactivation and activation are observed, while the catalyst remains active for continuous POM reaction. Comprehensive characterizations suggest that this deactivation is not caused by traditional deactivation mechanisms with coke formation or Ni sintering. The formation of inactive NiTiO3 results in catalyst deactivation, which is formed between Ni and TiO2 support in the reductive atmosphere of POM products under high temperature due to strong metal-support interaction (SMSI). The simultaneous presence of oxidative and reductive atmospheres of the reactants and products in the POM reaction leads to the generation or demise of NiTiO3. The dynamic change of the Ni active sites during the in-situ reaction leads to the oscillation of the catalytic activity. This study sheds new light on the importance of SMSI in understanding the behavior of catalysts under working conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Oscillatory behavior of Ni/TiO2 catalyst during partial oxidation of methane: Understanding the role of strong metal-support interaction
